Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Marine and Atmospheric Processes
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides renewed funding for a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at SUNY Stony Brook. The program will support eight students during a ten week summer research program for three years. The program will include independent research projects by the students, participation in a semi-weekly summer lecture series on topics including scientific writing, science careers, ethics and data visualization. It will conclude with a written report and student poster presentations. Students will be encouraged to publish in peer-reviewed journals and participate in national conferences following the summer research program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU site program at the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences, Stony Brook University has provided research experiences in oceanographic and atmospheric processes for the past 12 years with a focus on the implications of global climate change. Our program has been unique emphasizing the interdisciplinary study of coastal ocean and atmospheric processes. As environmental problems take center stage, understanding the Earth's ocean and atmospheric systems is increasingly important.  The program has supported 46 male and 49 female undergraduates 17% of who represent diverse ethnic groups including Asian, Hispanic, Black and Pacific Islander, above average for OCE-funded REU site programs. Our emphasis has been on the integration of diverse research interests and expertise and has been very attractive to undergraduate students from across the continental U.S. and Puerto Rico who welcomed the opportunity to take advantage of their academic training in geology, biology, chemistry, physics or meteorology with engineering, and/or mathematics to examine environmental problems. Students most of whom have had few research opportunities at their home academic institutions, have been provided with individualized ‘hands-on’ research experiences during a 10 week period, the opportunity to work with distinguished scientists, to be challenged to apply their academic backgrounds and training to develop intuition about natural systems and processes, to learn problem solving skills, proposal writing, and presentation skills, and the opportunity to start building a network of contacts for graduate study and a future scientific career. Collaborative field and laboratory or computer-based projects involving REU students with dedicated mentors, has enabled undergraduates to appreciate the significance of teamwork in addressing specific scientific questions or gaining maximum insight into a particular phenomenon or process.

 Coastal zones are particularly vulnerable to climate variability and change. Projected rates of sea-level rise over the next century can be expected to contribute significantly to physical changes along open-ocean shorelines. Predicting the nature and magnitude of these changes is essential for understanding the impacts to humans, other organisms, and the environment. Greater numbers and more intense storms cause coastal flooding, erode beaches, and increase the salinity of rivers, coastal bays, and groundwater tables. Improving the predictive capability of coastal meteorology for example, requires detailed knowledge of near-shore phenomena and air-sea-interactions as well as large-scale atmospheric dynamics and coastal ocean circulation. Our approach has taken advantage of the inter- and multi-disciplinary research interests and expertise of our faculty, connections they have with other scientists and conservations in order to tackle critical and timely issues, and an enthusiasm for stimulating bright young people who will be our next generation of scientists. The focus of student projects during the summer of 2010 provides an excellent example of the experiences we have provided bright undergraduates many of whom have gone on to graduate school programs followed by careers in academia, government agencies, and the private sector.
